transcript:
Patient: One small step I'd like to take this week is to finish sanding all the shelves. That's been a sticking point for me because I keep second-guessing whether I've gotten them smooth enough. But I think if I can just focus on making progress rather than achieving perfection, I can get it done.

Therapist: That's a great goal, Robert. Focusing on progress rather than perfection is key. And remember, even if the shelves aren't perfectly smooth, that doesn't mean the whole project is ruined. It's about the overall functionality and the effort you're putting in, not just the small details. What thoughts do you anticipate might come up as you work on sanding the shelves this week?

Patient: I know I'll probably start thinking things like "This isn't good enough" or "I'm never going to finish this project." Those perfectionistic thoughts tend to creep in and derail me.

Therapist: That's really insightful to anticipate those thoughts ahead of time. That gives us a chance to plan how you might respond to them. What could you say to yourself in those moments to challenge those perfectionistic thoughts?

Patient: I guess I could remind myself that done is better than perfect. And that the goal is to have a functional bookshelf, not a masterpiece. I could also try to focus on how far I've come with the project rather than how far I still have to go.

Therapist: Those are great strategies, Robert. Focusing on the progress you've made and the overall goal of functionality can help take the pressure off of achieving perfection. And remember, you can always use your thought records to work through those perfectionistic thoughts if they start to feel overwhelming. Do you feel like you have a good plan for tackling the sanding this week?

Patient: Yeah, I think so. It's helpful to have some specific strategies to use when those negative thoughts come up. I know it won't be easy, but I feel a bit more prepared now.

Therapist: That's great, Robert. And remember, it's okay if it's not easy. The goal is not to eliminate those negative thoughts completely, but rather to learn how to manage them and keep making progress despite them. I have confidence in your ability to do that. Before we wrap up, let's do a quick check-in on how you're feeling now.

Patient: I'm feeling a bit more hopeful than when we started, to be honest. I know I still have a lot of work to do, but it feels good to have a plan and some strategies to try. I appreciate you taking the time to break things down with me.

Therapist: It's my pleasure, Robert. I'm glad you're feeling more hopeful. That's a great sign that you're engaging with the therapy process and starting to see some benefits. Remember, progress isn't always linear, so there will be ups and downs. But as long as you keep showing up and putting in the effort, you will continue to see changes over time. For homework this week, I'd like you to continue working on the sleep hygiene plan we discussed, practice challenging those perfectionistic thoughts around the bookshelf project, and keep logging instances of all-or-nothing thinking and disqualifying the positive. Does that feel manageable?

Patient: It feels like a lot, but I know it's important work. I'll do my best to stay on top of it all. I might need to set some reminders for myself to help me stay on track.

Therapist: That's a great idea, Robert. Using reminders can be really helpful, especially when you're trying to build new habits. And remember, it's okay if you don't do everything perfectly. The goal is just to keep practicing and making progress. We can always troubleshoot any challenges that come up at our next session. Speaking of which, let's go ahead and schedule that now. How does this same time next week work for you?

Patient: That works for me. I'll put it in my calendar as soon as we hang up.

Therapist: Great. And in the meantime, don't hesitate to reach out if you need any support. I'm here for you, even between sessions. You've got this, Robert. I'm really proud of the work you're doing.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. That means a lot. I'll do my best to keep up the momentum this week.

Therapist: I know you will, Robert. I have full faith in you. Take care until next time.

Session Summary:
- Reviewed patient's experience with the Downward Arrow Technique and identified core beliefs around incompetence and being unlovable
- Introduced cognitive distortions, specifically all-or-nothing thinking and disqualifying the positive, and practiced challenging these distortions
- Discussed patient's progress with the bookshelf project and set a goal for sanding the shelves this week, focusing on progress rather than perfection
- Developed a sleep hygiene plan to address patient's sleep disturbances, including a consistent sleep schedule, relaxing bedtime routine, and limiting screen time before bed
- Checked in on patient's current mood and assigned homework: continue sleep hygiene plan, challenge perfectionistic thoughts around bookshelf project, log instances of all-or-nothing thinking and disqualifying the positive

Techniques used:
- Thought records
- Modified worry time
- Downward Arrow Technique
- Challenging cognitive distortions
- Sleep hygiene
- Behavioral activation with bookshelf project

Homework assigned:
- Continue practicing thought records
- Use modified worry time daily
- Practice Downward Arrow Technique to identify core beliefs
- Log instances of all-or-nothing thinking and disqualifying the positive
- Implement sleep hygiene plan: consistent sleep schedule, relaxing bedtime routine, limiting screen time before bed
- Work on sanding shelves for bookshelf project, focusing on progress rather than perfection

Patient's progress and challenges:
- Showing increased insight into connection between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors
- Actively engaging in practicing CBT skills
- Made progress on bookshelf project but struggling with perfectionism
- Sleep disturbances continue to be a challenge
- Depression symptoms remain present, with feelings of worthlessness, guilt, and loneliness being current challenges

Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
- Core belief: "I'm incompetent"
- Core belief: "I'm unlovable"
- Intermediate belief: "If I don't do things perfectly, I'm a failure"

Plan for next session:
- Review patient's experience with logging cognitive distortions
- Continue practicing cognitive restructuring using thought records
- Follow up on patient's progress with sleep hygiene plan and bookshelf project
- Explore patient's relationship with his daughter and discuss any updates or challenges
- Introduce additional cognitive distortions and practice challenging them
